item.title: No title
The Hive at Kew Gardens
item.description:
The Hive at Kew Gardens

Science and beauty come together at Kew this summer, as we explore the journey of the British bee through UK innovation and design. An open-air structure standing at 17 metres tall and weighing in at 40 tonnes, The Hive encapsulates the story of the honey bee and the important role of pollination in feeding the planet, through an immersive sound and visual experience.

item.title: Secret life of bees: personalities of insects revealed for first time in lifelong study
item.description:
Secret life of bees: personalities of insects revealed for first time in lifelong study

Dr James Makinson, one of the researchers from the School of Biological and Chemical Sciences at Queen Mary, said: "One bee was something of a lifelong vagabond, never settling down on a single patch of flowers.

item.title: Nurturing Bees, Soils with Buckwheat
item.description:
Nurturing Bees, Soils with Buckwheat

By William Scheick Contributing Editor The communal complexity and environmental essentialness of bees have always fascinated me. As the number of honey and native bees has disturbingly dwindled during recent years as a result of diseases, various "cides" and habitat losses, my interest in them has only deepened (see "Beeing in the Garden," Texas Gardener, March-April 2008).

item.title: Royal Jelly Isn't What Makes a Queen Bee a Queen Bee
item.description:
Royal Jelly Isn't What Makes a Queen Bee a Queen Bee

For decades, scientists thought an excess of something special, a substance called royal jelly, elevated a regular honey bee larva to a queen. New research suggests we had it backward: It's what future queens aren't fed that matters. Royal jelly, which also is called "bee milk," looks like white snot.

item.title: Insects have consciousness, a new study has found
item.description:
Insects have consciousness, a new study has found

Insects have a form of consciousness, according to a new paper that might show us how our own began. Brain scans of insects appear to indicate that they have the capacity to be conscious and show egocentric behaviour, apparently indicating that they have such a thing as subjective experience.

item.title: Buying Organic Honey? Here's What You Should Know.
item.description:
Buying Organic Honey? Here's What You Should Know.

"It takes two million individual blossoms to produce a pound of honey," explains Zac Browning, owner of Browning's Honey Company in Jamestown, North Dakota. On a June morning, his hives are humming. The little sacs on the bees' hind legs are bright yellow with pollen from dandelion, clover, and other wild plants blooming around the apiary.
